name: limestone production, crushed, washed | limestone, crushed, washed | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/8729/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of washed crushed limestone. IInfrastructure data are estimated based on a tour and sketches of the process. The value of the infrastructure is normalized with a annual production capacity of about 195'000 tons of product per year. ;This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of washed crushed limestone. Infrastructure data is estimated based on a tour and sketches of the process, and then normalized with a annual production capacity of about 195'000 tons of product per year. 

From the reception of mined limestone, at the factory gate.

The activity ends with the crushed limestone. The dataset includes the different production processes (crushing, washing, and transportation by conveyor belt), the energy consumption for buildings heating and the infratructure of the production process. The dataset doesn't include the infrastructure for electricity transportation from power plant to company.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/08:Other mining and quarrying/081:Quarrying of stone, sand and clay/0810:Quarrying of stone, sand and clay
tags: Sector: Resource Extraction; Minerals; Cement & Concrete

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data is based on a Swiss company.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The current Swiss technology is considered. The company works on a technically high level; heavy machines (excl. building machines) are operated electrically; air recirculated in closed loop to avoid dust emissions; ground water used for washing.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data is based on a Swiss company, for the year 2001.

exchanges.description:
Limestone is a naturally occurring mineral that consists principally of calcium carbonate but may also contain magnesium carbonate as a secondary component. It is found in many forms and is classified in terms of its origin, chemical composition, structure, and geological formation. Limestone occurs widely throughout the world and is an essential raw material for many industries.
Limestone is generally used for construction, cement, quicklime, agriculture, metal refining and flue gas desulphurisation:

Construction: Limestone is the most widely used crushed rock, although it is generally sold in form of sand and gravel.

Cement: The production of cement is the main use for chalk, and a major use for dense, high-calcium limestone. Approximately 1.1 t of limestone is required for 1 t of cement.

Quicklime: Approximately 1.8 t of limestone is required per 1.0 t of quicklime.

Agriculture: Many crops grow best under neutral to slightly acid conditions (i.e., pH between 6 and 7). Thus soils which are more acidic than pH 6 generally benefit from the application of limestone.

Metal refining: When limestone is used in metal refining it is initially converted to quicklime, which reacts with acidic oxides (e.g., SiO2, Al2O, and Fe2O3) to produce molten slag.

Flue gas desulphurisation: A growing use of limestone is in the treatment of flue gas from combustion processes to remove sulphur dioxide.

exchanges.description:
Estimation, based on company data. The total water consumption for hydratation by 2001 was 11.010 m3 and the total pumped water was 19.450 m3. Half of this amount is assumed that is used for the process and the rest for limestone crushing (for kiln).
Calculated based on literature(IPPC, 2010, Cement, Lime and Magnesium Oxide Manufacturing Industries; Byers, W., 2003, Industrial Water Management), (Vionnet, S., Quantis Water Database - Technical Report, 2012). The water use is 0.5 - 2 m3/tonne of limestone, 85% is recycled, so only 15% of this amount needs to be added from fresh water. The amount of water extracted based on IPPC, the evaporation rate based on Byers. It includes the process of crushing, but there is no water use during crushing. The amount of water used during washing varies depending on the amount of inpurities. The process ends when the limestone is in such a status that it can be fed into the cement kiln.

The water use is 0.5 - 2 m3/tonne of limestone, 85% is recycled, so only 15% of this amount needs to be added from fresh water. The amount of water extracted based on IPPC, the evaporation rate based on Byers. It includes the process of crushing, but there is no water use during crushing. The amount of water used during washing varies depending on the amount of inpurities. The process ends when the limestone is in such a status that it can be fed into the cement kiln.
Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres' comment field.
